bestBHT.bht: In response to the criticism from religious leaders, Jesus references the story of David and the showbread to emphasize the misguided nature of their petty concerns. By highlighting the significance of understanding the true purpose of the Sabbath, Jesus exposes their legalistic approach. This encounter underscores the tension between rigid adherence to religious rituals and Jesus' focus on the deeper significance underlying the observance of the Sabbath.

Marvin Vincent: The shew - bread. See on Mark 2:26.
Archibald T. Robertson: It was an overwhelming and crushing reply to these pettifogging ceremonialists to which they could not reply, but which increased their anger.
Not in Mark and Matthew. See Matthew 12:1-8; Mark 2:23-28 for discussion of details about the shewbread and the five arguments in defence of his conduct on the sabbath.
On the same day beholding one working on the sabbath he said to him: Man, if you know what you are doing, happy are you; but if you do not know, cursed are you and a transgressor of the law.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus responds to the criticism of the religious leaders by referencing the story of David and the showbread, which is peculiar to the book of Luke. This was a crushing response to the ceremonialists, implying that their petty concerns about keeping the Sabbath were misguided. Jesus goes on to assert that if one truly understands the purpose of the Sabbath, they would know the significance of their actions. This altercation highlights the tension between the legalistic view of the religious leaders and Jesus' emphasis on the true essence of the law.

Jesus gives a powerful response to the religious leaders, drawing from the story of David and the showbread. This incident, unique to Luke's account, serves as a rebuke to the petty concerns of the ceremonialists. Jesus asserts that understanding the true purpose of the Sabbath is crucial, as it determines whether one is blessed or cursed and a transgressor of the law. This encounter highlights the tension between legalistic views and Jesus' emphasis on the deeper meaning behind the Sabbath.

In response to the criticism from religious leaders, Jesus references the story of David and the showbread to emphasize the misguided nature of their petty concerns. By highlighting the significance of understanding the true purpose of the Sabbath, Jesus exposes their legalistic approach. This encounter underscores the tension between rigid adherence to religious rituals and Jesus' focus on the deeper significance underlying the observance of the Sabbath.

Jesus offers a powerful response to the religious leaders, using the story of David and the showbread to expose the misguided nature of their concerns. By emphasizing the importance of understanding the true purpose of the Sabbath, Jesus challenges their legalistic approach. This encounter highlights the tension between rigid adherence to religious rituals and Jesus' emphasis on the deeper meaning behind the observance of the Sabbath.

Jesus provides a poignant rejoinder to the religious leaders by invoking the incident of David and the showbread, highlighting the futility of their petty objections. His assertion regarding the significance of understanding the true essence of the Sabbath serves as a counterpoint to their legalistic outlook. This encounter illuminates the prevalent tension between rigid adherence to religious customs and Jesus' emphasis on the underlying purpose and spirit of the Sabbath observance.
